title: How to Organize the Area Under Your Sink

steps.headline: Pull everything out of the cupboard.
steps.description: Pull everything out that you currently store under your kitchen sink. Take stock of everything you currently store there and move it away from the area, so that you have room to clean.

steps.headline: Clean inside the cupboard with disinfecting spray and a washcloth.
steps.description: Spray a disinfecting mixture all over the walls and floor of the cupboard, making sure to get in the top corners. Scrub all the mildew out. Then wipe the residue away with a sponge or washcloth. If you don't have any disinfectant, you can make a homemade disinfectant.

steps.headline: Line the bottom of your cupboard with a shelf liner to help with stains.
steps.description: Buy a roll of shelf liner to line the floor of this area. Lining the bottom of this space will not only make it look better, but it will also improve the grip on the bottom of the area, help absorb spills, and avoid stains. Alternatively, buy adhesive contact paper to liven up the look of the area beneath your sink. Contact paper comes in a variety of styles and can be bought at most general or craft stores.

steps.headline: Throw away or recycle what you don’t need.
steps.description: Toss any old cleaning supplies that you no longer use, like unused cleaning sprays, old dingy sponges and rags, or any expired products. Check the products you’re tossing for the recycling symbol; some of the containers you’re throwing away may be recyclable, especially if they're plastic. Pour any old cleaning product into the sink drain, then run the tap for about 10 seconds.

steps.headline: Sort through and group the remaining items.
steps.description: Group items by function so that you can put them together in containers later. For example, group your sponges, rags, washcloths, and scrubbing brushes together. Group all your cleaning mixtures together as well. If the area under your kitchen sink is full of paper towels or plastic bags, try moving the majority of them to a garage or pantry, and leave only what you need (5-10 plastic bags and 2 rolls of paper towels, for example) beneath your sink.

steps.headline: Store capsules of dish detergent in locking jars.
steps.description: Keep your dish detergent in safe locking jars. Label the jars with small stick-on labels for easy identification. Dish detergent can be extremely toxic if ingested, so make sure it’s out of the way of small children’s hands.

steps.headline: Take items out of packaging to conserve space.
steps.description: Remove items like sponges and wash cloths from their packaging in order to more easily store them and make them look at home in the area beneath your sink.

steps.headline: Label a series of stacking containers for storage.
steps.description:
Buy stacking containers to make use of the ample vertical space inside your kitchen cupboard. You can also use small stick-on labels to identify your stacking containers. Try using different containers for:
Tools (small flashlight, dish strainer)
Sponges
Brushes (old toothbrushes for cleaning small areas)
Rags

steps.headline: Keep sprays and cleaning towels in a movable cleaning caddy.
steps.description:
Store your cleaning sprays in a movable caddy with a handle, so you can take it out and use it whenever you need to clean around the kitchen. Keep the following items in your kitchen cleaning caddy:
All-purpose cleaner
Disinfectant spray
1 wash cloth and 1 sponge
Glass cleaner
1 SOS pad

steps.headline: Use an over-the-door organizer to store sponges or brushes.
steps.description: Purchase a small over-the-door organizer with a tray. Measure your cabinet door before purchasing the organizer; you want one that is just smaller than your door. This can be used to store sponges and brushes that you use often while doing dishes. Some over-the-door organizers come with a towel bar on the other side. If the organizer’s over-the-door hooks are a little wider than the door, causing them to shake and rattle when you open it, apply plumber’s putty to the underside of the hooks to help them stay in place.

steps.headline: Hang dish gloves from a temporary hook with a binder clip.
steps.description: Hang a temporary wire hook on the wall of your cabinet. Attach a binder clip to the openings of your rubber gloves and hang them from the hook. This will help to keep unsightly gloves out of your way in the kitchen.

steps.headline: Move everything to the front.
steps.description: Move the items inside this area to the very front, so that you’re not constantly reaching around things to get to them. The easier it is to access your items, the more likely it is that you’ll actually use them. In addition, pulling everything to the front makes it look more organized. You can use the extra space in the back of your cupboard to store extra plastic bags, rags, or paper towels.

steps.headline: Clean your kitchen often.
steps.description: To ensure that you’re getting the most use out of the items below your kitchen sink, clean your kitchen once a week. Take the kitchen caddy out so that you’re interacting with the area often. This will allow you to take stock of what you're running out of, and what needs replacing. Wash or replace your rags and sponges once a week or every other week. When left wet, these items accumulate dangerous bacteria quickly, so don't let them sit around for longer than 2 weeks.

steps.headline: Clean the area under your kitchen sink once a month.
steps.description: Once a month, take everything out of this area and clean the floor and walls of it with a disinfecting spray and a washcloth or sponge. Dry it with a dry cloth, then place your items back into the cupboard. Be sure to keep everything to the front. The more often you clean this area, the less work you'll have to do each time you clean it.

text:
Cleaning Out the Space Pull everything out of the cupboard. Pull everything out that you currently store under your kitchen sink. Take stock of everything you currently store there and move it away from the area, so that you have room to clean. Clean inside the cupboard with disinfecting spray and a washcloth. Spray a disinfecting mixture all over the walls and floor of the cupboard, making sure to get in the top corners. Scrub all the mildew out. Then wipe the residue away with a sponge or washcloth. If you don't have any disinfectant, you can make a homemade disinfectant. Line the bottom of your cupboard with a shelf liner to help with stains. Buy a roll of shelf liner to line the floor of this area. Lining the bottom of this space will not only make it look better, but it will also improve the grip on the bottom of the area, help absorb spills, and avoid stains. Alternatively, buy adhesive contact paper to liven up the look of the area beneath your sink. Contact paper comes in a variety of styles and can be bought at most general or craft stores. Throw away or recycle what you don’t need. Toss any old cleaning supplies that you no longer use, like unused cleaning sprays, old dingy sponges and rags, or any expired products. Check the products you’re tossing for the recycling symbol; some of the containers you’re throwing away may be recyclable, especially if they're plastic. Pour any old cleaning product into the sink drain, then run the tap for about 10 seconds. Sort through and group the remaining items. Group items by function so that you can put them together in containers later. For example, group your sponges, rags, washcloths, and scrubbing brushes together. Group all your cleaning mixtures together as well. If the area under your kitchen sink is full of paper towels or plastic bags, try moving the majority of them to a garage or pantry, and leave only what you need (5-10 plastic bags and 2 rolls of paper towels, for example) beneath your sink. Organizing Your Supplies Store capsules of dish detergent in locking jars. Keep your dish detergent in safe locking jars. Label the jars with small stick-on labels for easy identification. Dish detergent can be extremely toxic if ingested, so make sure it’s out of the way of small children’s hands. Take items out of packaging to conserve space. Remove items like sponges and wash cloths from their packaging in order to more easily store them and make them look at home in the area beneath your sink. Label a series of stacking containers for storage. Buy stacking containers to make use of the ample vertical space inside your kitchen cupboard. You can also use small stick-on labels to identify your stacking containers. Try using different containers for:
Tools (small flashlight, dish strainer)
Sponges
Brushes (old toothbrushes for cleaning small areas)
Rags Keep sprays and cleaning towels in a movable cleaning caddy. Store your cleaning sprays in a movable caddy with a handle, so you can take it out and use it whenever you need to clean around the kitchen. Keep the following items in your kitchen cleaning caddy:
All-purpose cleaner
Disinfectant spray
1 wash cloth and 1 sponge
Glass cleaner
1 SOS pad Use an over-the-door organizer to store sponges or brushes. Purchase a small over-the-door organizer with a tray. Measure your cabinet door before purchasing the organizer; you want one that is just smaller than your door. This can be used to store sponges and brushes that you use often while doing dishes. Some over-the-door organizers come with a towel bar on the other side. If the organizer’s over-the-door hooks are a little wider than the door, causing them to shake and rattle when you open it, apply plumber’s putty to the underside of the hooks to help them stay in place. Hang dish gloves from a temporary hook with a binder clip. Hang a temporary wire hook on the wall of your cabinet. Attach a binder clip to the openings of your rubber gloves and hang them from the hook. This will help to keep unsightly gloves out of your way in the kitchen. Keeping the Area Clean Move everything to the front. Move the items inside this area to the very front, so that you’re not constantly reaching around things to get to them. The easier it is to access your items, the more likely it is that you’ll actually use them. In addition, pulling everything to the front makes it look more organized. You can use the extra space in the back of your cupboard to store extra plastic bags, rags, or paper towels. Clean your kitchen often. To ensure that you’re getting the most use out of the items below your kitchen sink, clean your kitchen once a week. Take the kitchen caddy out so that you’re interacting with the area often. This will allow you to take stock of what you're running out of, and what needs replacing. Wash or replace your rags and sponges once a week or every other week. When left wet, these items accumulate dangerous bacteria quickly, so don't let them sit around for longer than 2 weeks. Clean the area under your kitchen sink once a month. Once a month, take everything out of this area and clean the floor and walls of it with a disinfecting spray and a washcloth or sponge. Dry it with a dry cloth, then place your items back into the cupboard. Be sure to keep everything to the front. The more often you clean this area, the less work you'll have to do each time you clean it.
